column4: Hi, I'm running Ubuntu 10.04. Running update brings up a message to do a partial upgrade, is there a way around this?
sounds like your last update was interupted
don't worry, that won't move you to a new release
The partial upgrade shows a list of everything installed to be removed, which is literally everything on the computer.
what update got interrupted?
No idea, I always complete any update successfully.
when was the last time you did an update?
A week ago.
is there a kernel update in the list?
I don't know, there's some gnome2 stuff and metacity, and a bunch of libs.
if there isn't a kernel update in there then go for it
I did a partial upgrade last year, which caused the computer to stop working. So I want to avoid doing a partial upgrade, and just want to continue with normal updates. Is there a way to do that?
partial upgrades are only triggered if the previous update failed, you need to go through with them
I don't have a spare drive for backup, if I do the upgrade and have data loss, can I restore it?
not that i know of, you really ought to have a backup
i wouldn't expect data loss, just an updating of packages
Thats what worries me about partial upgrades, I lost all my uni work last year.
if it goes wrong you can mount it from a livecd and recover what you need
but seriously thats the backwards way of doing it, you should have backups in the first place
I'll wait another week or two in that case, because I'm getting an extra hard disk.
good, better safe than sorry
i don't mean to lecture you but i find that if you don't have backups you are essentially saying your data isn't worth keeping safe
Thanks, I'll get a backup disk, and do the upgrade. I was out of cash for a while, so buying a hard disk was out of the question.
